questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following anti-epileptics is an AMPA glutamate receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Perampanel is a selective non-competitive antagonist of the AMPA-type glutamate receptor. It is 
approved for adjunctive therapy of focal-onset seizures. Options A and B: Levetiracetam and brivaracetam act on SV2A proteins and modulates GABA and 
glutamate release. Option D: Rufinamide acts on voltage-gated sodium channels.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following mechanisms of action is observed with levetiracetam?

options.c: Binding to synaptic vesicular protein SV2A

questions.explanation:
Levetiracetam has a binding affinity to synaptic vesicular protein SV2A. SV2A plays a role in 
vesicle recycling following exocytosis of neurotransmitter When levetiracetam bind to this synaptic vesicular protein, it decreases the release of excitatory 
neurotransmitter glutamate thus preventing seizures. Levetiracetam also inhibits N-type Ca2+ channels and Ca2+ release from intracellular stores.Thus, 
it is considered a broad-spectrum antiepileptic as it has an effect on multiple channels.

questions.question:
Question 3: A known epileptic patient on levetiracetam has been seizure-free for 2 years. But he develops 
agitation and anger issues interfering with his day-to-day activities as a result of the drug 
intake. Which of the following measures is to be taken next?

options.a: Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
options.b: Continue levetriacetam since a 5 year seizure free interval is needed
options.c: Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic
options.d: Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.explanation:
The mood changes observed in the above patient must be due to an adverse effect of 
levetiracetam. Abrupt stoppage of the drug can result in rebound seizures. So the best 
management will be to slowly taper the drug over the next 6 months. Adverse effects of levetiracetam: • Somnolence • Asthenia • Ataxia • Dizziness. • Mood and behavioral changes • Psychotic reactions (rare) 295 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Tiagabine has been initiated as an adjunctive treatment for focal seizures in a patient. What is 
the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Tiagabine acts by inhibiting the GAT1 GABA transporter, thereby reducing its reuptake into 
neurons. It also increases the duration of inhibitory impulses in the synapse by prolonging the 
action of GABA. Tiagabine is approved as an add-on therapy for refractory partial seizures with or without 
generalization. Other antiepileptic drugs that have GABA enhancing activity are vigabatrin and stiripentol.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 25-year-old patient diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome was prescribed a drug with 
NMDA antagonist activity. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Felbamate is the NMDA receptor antagonist prescribed to this patient. It also potentiates GABA 
action. It is indicated in refractory primary or secondary generalized seizures and Lennox-Gastaut 
syndrome. Felbamate is associated with aplastic anemia and liver failure. Option A: Memantine is used in Alzheimer’s disease. Option B: Riluzole is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Option C: Ketamine causes dissociative anesthesia and used in general anesthesia.

questions.question:
Question 6: An antiepileptic agent which acts by opening neuronal potassium channels was prescribed to 
a patient admitted to the neurology ward. On discharge, the patient was asked to have a 
regular ophthalmological examination every 6 months. Which drug is most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ezogabine (retigabine) acts by opening neuronal potassium channels. By opening the K+ channels, 
stabilizes the resting membrane potential and reduces the excitability of the nerve membrane. FDA recommends that patients on chronic ezogabine therapy need visual acuity and 
fundus examination every 6 months due to the possibility of retinal abnormalities. Option B: Rufinamide acts by prolonging an inactive state of the Na+ channel. Option C: Vigabatrin is a GABA transaminase inhibitor. Option D: Gabaculine is an irreversible GABA reuptake inhibitor, that has only experimental 
value, due to high toxicity.

questions.question: Question 7: All of the following statements are true about zonisamide except:

options.b: Nephrolithiasis is not a side effect
options.d: Blocks low voltage gated Na+ channel

questions.explanation:
Nephrolithiasis is a side effect of zonisamide. Zonisamide is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic, that acts by blocking low voltage Na+ channels and 
T type calcium channels. It also has carbonic anhydrase inhibiting activity that may result in 
metabolic acidosis and the formation of renal stones. It is used in the treatment of focal seizures. 296 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Patients on which of the following antiepileptic drugs will experience weight loss? 288 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Topiramate causes weight loss as one of its common side effects. Topiramate has mixed mechanisms of action: • Reduces voltage gate Na+ currents • Activates hyperpolarizing K+ currents • Enhances postsynaptic GABAA current • Limits the activation of AMPA subtype of glutamate receptors. Topiramate is used in focal seizures, GTCS and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. The side effects: • Cognitive impairment • Weight loss • Fatigue • Renal calculi Sodium valproate, vigabatrin (highest incidence), and carbamazepine cause weight gain.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 55-year-old patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pain over a healed 
dermatomal rash on his lateral chest wall. Gabapentin was prescribed to this patient. The 
analgesic activity of this drug is mainly exerted by which of the following?

options.a: Increasing the duration of GABA Cl- channel opening
options.c: Inhibiting the uptake of GABA at the presynaptic membrane

questions.explanation:
Gabapentin exerts its analgesic activity by inhibiting the Ca2+ channel current in this patient who 
is most likely suffering from post-herpetic neuralgia. Gabapentin and pregabalin have close structural similarity to GABA. Still, they do not act through 
the effects of GABA receptors or any other mechanism related to GABA-mediated 
neurotransmission. They inhibit the calcium channel current which decreases the entry of calcium in the presynaptic 
neuron. When calcium entry in the neuron is reduced, there is a decrease in the release of 
glutamate. This lowers the excitability of the neuron, thus reducing seizure activity. Therapeutic use of these drugs: Gabapentin: Focal seizures, postherpetic neuralgia pain Pregabalin: Focal seizures, postherpetic neuralgia pain, diabetic neuropathy pain, spinal cord 
injury pain, fibromyalgia pain.

questions.question:
Question 10: An infant presents with sudden jerky movements of the head, neck and arms. On EEG 
evaluation, a characteristic pattern of hypsarrhythmia is observed. Which is the GABA 
transaminase inhibitor approved for the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with hypsarrytmia on EEG is suggestive of West 
syndrome. Vigabatrin is an inhibitor of the GABA transaminase that can be used in this 297 
Sold by @itachibot condition. Inhibition of the enzyme GABA transaminase leads to an increase in the concentration of GABA in 
the synaptic cleft which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. This contributes to its anticonvulsant 
property of vigabatrin. West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. It is characterized by a 
triad of: • Infantile seizures (also called salaam spells) • Developmental regression • Hypsarrhythmia i.e Himalayan wave pattern on EEG Treatment of West syndrome includes: • ACTH • Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.question: Question 11: What is the drug of choice in the treatment of infantile spasms?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice in the treatment of infantile spasms or West syndrome is adrenocorticotropic 
hormone (ACTH.) The mechanism of action of ACTH or glucocorticoids is unknown but may involve a reduction in 
inflammatory processes. Vigabatrin is used if the spasms are associated with tuberous sclerosis. Other antiseizure medications that may be helpful are valproate, topiramate, zonisamide, or 
benzodiazepines.

questions.question:
Question 12: 289 
Sold by @itachibot Which antiepileptic drug is associated with permanent visual loss?
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin is associated with progressive and permanent visual loss. It is a GABA transaminase inhibitor indicated in: • West syndrome associated with tuberous sclerosis • Refractory focal seizures with impaired awareness.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs are approved for prophylaxis in patients suffering 
from migraines?
questions.explanation:
Sodium valproate, topiramate and gabapentin are approved anti-epileptics for use in prophylaxis 
of migraine. Carbamazepine, phenytoin and rufinamide are not used for prophylaxis of a migraine. 298 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 22-year-old female is brought to the casualty with seizures for the past 10 minutes. History 
from relatives suggests no seizure-free intervals in the past 10 minutes. After stabilizing the 
vitals of the patient, which is the first drug you administer to the patient?
questions.explanation:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first drug used in the management is 
lorazepam. Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired 
consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, it is defined as any one of the 
following: • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures. Management of status epilepticus:

questions.question:
Question 15: A 25-year-old newly married female comes to the OPD with a positive urine pregnancy test. 
Her history is suggestive of antiepileptic use since 8 years. Which of the following statements 
is incorrect about further management in this patient?

options.a: Anti epileptic agents has to be continued at stabilised doses
options.b: Immediately stop antiepileptics once pregnancy is detected
options.d: No antiepiletic is deemed safe in pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Stopping antiepileptics abruptly once pregnancy is detected in this patient is not recommended. If 
this is done, then there is a lot of risk to the fetus by uncontrolled seizures and can result in 
anoxia and intellectual disability. Antiepileptics have to be continued and then the dose can be 
tapered slowly if there are no episodes of seizures. Management of seizures in pregnancy: • If the patient is a known case of seizure and is on any antiepileptic drug: The same prescribed 
drug is continued • If the first episode occurs during pregnancy: The drug preferred is either lamotrigine or 
levetiracetam • Folic acid (1-4 mg/day) should be given to all No antiepileptic is deemed safe in pregnancy. So, it is important to have the patient on 
monotherapy at the lowest effective dose, especially during the first trimester. 299 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: An infant is born with a birth defect as shown in the image below. It is the most common 
teratogenic effect of:
questions.explanation:
The above illustration is suggestive of an infant with spina bifida of the open type which is the 
most common teratogenic effect of sodium valproate. Option A: Phenytoin is usually associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Option B: Topiramate has shown growth defects in animal studies and hypospadias have been 
shown in the male fetus but the definite relationship is lacking. Option D: Phenobarbital has teratogenic effects similar to phenytoin.

questions.question: Question 17: Which is the treatment of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) in pregnancy is levetiracetam. 
Lamotrigine or levetiracetam are alternative first-line in pregnancy as they have fewer teratogenic 
effects. The drug of choice for JME is valproate. However, in pregnant women or women of childbearing 
age, valproate should be avoided because of the increased risks of fetal malformations and 
neurodevelopmental delay. Carbamazepine, vigabatrin, and phenytoin are not indicated in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy as they 
may worsen myoclonic jerks and absence seizures.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 29-year-old primigravida, at 4-months period of gestation and history of juvenile myoclonic 
epilepsy, visits your clinic. She has been regularly taking sodium valproate and is now 291 
Sold by @itachibot concerned about the medication possibly affecting her child. What would you suggest to this 
patient?

options.a: Immediately taper valproate and start lamotrigine
options.b: Continue valproate with serial drug monitoring

questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the patient should be advised to continue valproate, and serial drug 
monitoring should be done. Valproate has a higher teratogenic potential. It is usually avoided before conception if other 
antiepileptics with less teratogenicity (lamotrigine. levetiracetam) can be used. But for a woman 
who is pregnant and is already taking valproate, changing the drug is not recommended. Option A - The patient is presenting in the second trimester when organogenesis would have been 
complete. Therefore, tapering the drug and introducing lamotrigine is not an option as 
precipitating seizures has a greater risk of fetal harm at this stage. Option C: Carbamazepine is not indicated in JME as it may worsen the myoclonic jerks and 
absence seizures. Option D- Adding additional drugs to stabilized doses may increase teratogenicity. So adding 
lamotrigine to valproate is also not a viable option.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following is recommended for prophylaxis in a pregnant woman who is on 
anti-epileptic drugs with an enzyme-inducing property?
questions.explanation:
300 
Sold by @itachibot Vitamin K is recommended for prophylaxis in pregnant women who are on antiepileptic drugs 
having enzyme-inducing properties. Antiepileptic drugs with enzyme inducing properties: • Phenytoin • Carbamazepine • Oxcarbazepine • Topiramate • Phenobarbital • Primidone They induce CYP enzymes that interfere with the metabolism of vitamin K. Deficiency of vitamin 
K-dependent clotting factors can occur in the newborn leading to coagulopathy and intracerebral 
hemorrhage. Although hemorrhage is uncommon, the mother should be treated with oral vitamin K, 20 mg/day 
in the last two weeks of pregnancy. The infant should receive an intramuscular injection of 
vitamin K (1 mg) at birth.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following antiepileptics is effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but shows the 
highest propensity to cause rashes in young children warranting its withdrawal?
questions.explanation:
Lamotrigine is effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and has the highest propensity to cause 
rashes in young children. Lamotrigine is also associated with toxic epidermal necrosis and Stevens-Johnson Syndrome in 
some patients. The incidence of serious rash and other serious skin conditions is higher with 
lamotrigine than other anti-epileptics provided in the options. The occurrence of rash 
warrants the stoppage of the drug. Option A: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. It can cause 
fulminant hepatitis especially in children < 2 years. Option B: Levetiracetam is also effective in most of the seizures present in Lennox-Gastaut 
syndrome. It can increase blood pressure in children < 4 years. Option D: Vigabatrin is also effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, especially as an add-on 
therapy. It can cause permanent visual field defects.

questions.question:
Question 21: Patients receiving which of the following anti-microbial drugs are least likely to develop 
seizures?
questions.explanation:
Macrolides are the least likely anti-microbial out of the given options to cause seizures. Antimicrobials associated with causing seizures: • Beta-lactam and related compounds • Quinolones 301 
Sold by @itachibot • Acyclovir • Isoniazid • Ganciclovir Other groups of drugs that are implicated in causing epilepsy: • Alkylating agents - busulfan, chlorambucil • Antimalarials - chloroquine, mefloquine • Anesthetics/ analgesics - meperidine, fentanyl, tramadol, local anesthetics • Immunomodulatory drugs - cyclosporine, tacrolimus, interferons • Psychotropics: • Antidepressants - bupropion • Antipsychotics - clozapine • Anti-manic drugs - lithium • Drugs of abuse - amphetamine, cocaine, phencyclidine, methylphenidate • Miscellaneous - Theophylline, memantine.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following drugs of abuse is least likely to be associated with seizures?
questions.explanation:
Cannabinoids are being investigated for the treatment of various types of epilepsy and are least 
likely to cause seizures. Drugs of abuse that are implicated in causing seizures are: • Amphetamine • Cocaine • Phencyclidine • Methylphenidate

questions.question:
Question 23: A patient presented to the OPD with a skin rash for 3 days. He gives a history of antiepileptic 
drug use for 2 months and is ataxic on examination. He is diagnosed to have Stevens-Johnson 
syndrome. Which of the following drugs are implicated in these adverse effects?
questions.explanation:
Lamotrigine is known to cause such adverse effects in patients. Adverse effects of lamotrigine: • Skin rash • Stevens-Johnson syndrome • Dizziness • Diplopia • Sedation 302 
Sold by @itachibot • Ataxia • Headache

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following drugs if used can lead to behavioral effects such as aggression?
questions.explanation:
Children who are on levetiracetam have a higher risk of developing several behavioral side-effects 
such as aggression, hostility, and nervousness compared to children who do not use levetiracetam. These side effects are seen in less frequency with brivaracetam.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following drug is approved for use in fibromyalgia?
questions.explanation:
Pregabalin is approved for use in fibromyalgia. It is also approved for use in diabetic peripheral 
neuropathy. Mechanism of analgesic action: • Interacts at the binding site of the alpha, delta subunit of voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels • Correlates with decreased Ca2+ channel function and release of neurotransmitters • Decreased neurotransmitter release is associated with reduced neuronal hyperexcitability. Options A and C: Gabapentin and tiagabine are also useful in fibromyalgia but are not approved 
for this indication and are used off-label. Option D: Topiramate's efficacy is not encouraging in fibromyalgia and neuropathic pain.

questions.question: Question 26: What is the first-line treatment for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Vigabatrin is particularly effective in infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis and is 
considered the first-line treatment in this condition. ACTH is considered to be the drug of choice for infantile spasms that are not associated with 
tuberous sclerosis. 303 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-psychotics
